math_problem:
Find all the functions $f: \mathbb{R} \to\mathbb{R}$ such that
\[f(x-f(y))=f(f(y))+xf(y)+f(x)-1\]
for all $x,y \in \mathbb{R} $. Instead of determining all functions satisfying the given functional equation, simply find $k = p + 1/2$, where $p$ is the coefficient of the quadratic term derived from substituting an assumed quadratic form into the functional equation. Find all polynomials $f$ with real coefficients such that for all reals $a,b,c$ such that $ab+bc+ca = k$ we have the following relations
\[ f(a-b) + f(b-c) + f(c-a) = 2f(a+b+c). \]
